reviewText: An engaging period piece about a high school grad from a broken home (gypsy-like, yet caring mother and altogether absent father) in a desperate search to find the stolen Vette he helped restore in his high school shop class. Did California public schools have funding for that kind of project back in 1978? Probably not, but this movie is a superb showcase of Mark Hamill's physical acting ability and agility, natural comedic talent, and is a great historical recording of the Vegas of yesteryear. Also has a great plot twist and some bad guys who are really, really BAD guys. And I'd like to think that even back in the 70s it was not a common thing for high school graduates to pursue prostitution as a career choice (even if college wasn't an option), so suspend your disbelief and enjoy Annie Potts' comedic portrayal of a sometimes-unstable yet adorable protagonist and Hamill's eventual, true ally.
summary: A Showcase of Mark Hamill and the Vegas of Yesteryear

reviewText: Great movie, fun, easy to get lost in, very original plot, story is engaging, comedy is fresh.  There's just nothing bad about this movie. And when I first heard Mark Hamill was in this movie, I thought oh that's stupid.  He's Luke Skywalker, this isn't going to work.  Wow, I was so wrong!  This movie only proved Mark Hamill was not typecast and could do a great job playing other leading roles.  I did not see Luke Skywalker in this movie, but a very talented and capable Mark Hamill.  Very refreshing, and I enjoyed this movie thoroughly.  It's great to be able to watch and enjoy it again 30 years later.
summary: Great movie

reviewText: Well, I bought the DVD from Amazon (Thank You), and I realized I had forgotten a lot about this movie, which I hadn't seen in close to twenty years. Believe it or not, Mark Hamill is quite good as Kenny Dantley, a high school senior who rebuilds a junk Corvette in his auto-shop class, falls in love with it, and then loses it when it is stolen by the bad guys.  Hamill actually conveys more emotion in this movie than "Star Wars", the film which made him famous. Annie Potts, best known for her TV work on "Designing Women",is Vanessa, the hooker Kenny meets in Las Vegas while searching for the stolen Corvette. They have a pleasant, believable chemistry between them. Of course, the Corvette is the real star of the show, though it looks a lot more modified than I'd remembered; so much in fact, the front end of the vehicle doesn't really look like a Corvette. This movie was rated PG when it was released in 1978, but if it were released today, it would probably carry a PG-13 thanks to a brief topless scene by Potts (I'm not complaining).The DVD itself is no-frills, though it is in widescreen format and does include the trailer, which is in surprisingly good condition. The picture quality, in my opinion, is not bad, given the movie is from 1978 and probably not high on the film-restoration list at the studio. Some nighttime scenes are murky, but there are some daytime scenes which are remarkably crisp. The sound is good, particularly if you have a home theater system. The DVD is distributed by Warner Bros., though MGM was the studio that released the film to theaters."Corvette Summer" is a nice little movie that would probably never be made today. If you remember this movie from your childhood, re-visit it. For the price, it's well worth the money.
summary: Still a nice little Boy-meets-Car (and girl) movie

reviewText: Finally! MGM finally has released this summer "feel good" movie on dvd. The movie itself looks great on dvd--sharp with vivid colors. It is great to see it in widescreen and what a nice perk in having the theatrical trailer. However, I gave it four stars out of five because of the lack of extras. Mark Hamill and Annie Potts are still around--why not a commentary track with them? Or at least an interview? Sadly, Eugene Roche who played Mr. McGrath died just recently. Mark Hamill, Annie Potts, and a Corvette? A movie about summer fun and action? Buy it! You won't be disappointed.
summary: Corvette Summer finally Arrives in time for fall!

reviewText: I remember this movie well. First saw it on HBO in 1979 and it is one of my favorite coming of age movies. The Custom Corvette used in the film has been bashed by Corvette fans since this movie came out and with good reason, it is utterly hideous. Annie Potts is simply beautiful in this movie and although this was supposed to be Mark Hamil's post Star Wars debut, Potts, then an unknown, steals the movie. Our generation ( I was born in 65) will love this movie. Younger people will be puzzled by it.

reviewText: I remember when this movie was first released in the seventies. I couldn't believe this was the film that came out, just after Hamill's Star Wars debut.I remember scratching my head thinking,"why would a star like Hamill, do this little, nothing, car film?" Well, seeing this film again, over twenty years later, I realize what a hoot this gem of a film is.The movie is basically about a teenager searching for his stolen corvette and how he manages to fall in love with a goofy, wannabe hooker along the way. Its got everything from neat looking muscle cars to girls in halter tops and the guys sporting open shirts and blow dryed hair.Its a real pop culture treasure trove featuring energetic performances from both Hamill and a very young, 'Designing Women', Annie Potts.It isn't the greatest movie ever made, but it is two hours of seventies, retro fun.
summary: Seventies Retro and a Lot of Fun
Title: N/A

reviewText: Yeah, that's right, I'll admit it: I've been waiting for this one to be released on DVD. Is that so wrong? Back in '78, this was Mark Hamill's first post-Star Wars project; we were excited to see "Luke Skywalker" again; even if he wasn't Luke here. We were also excited because Corvette Summer boasted one of the coolest custom 'vettes we'd ever seen, not to mention Annie Potts as a "working girl" This is a nice time capsule of the late 70's, I would recommend to anyone who grew up in that decade, Star Wars fans in particular.Nostalgia aside this isn't a bad comic chase as Hamill ("Kenny" here) searches for his custom car, made by his own 2 hands, neither of which is robotic at this point, aided and hindered by Potts, as the love-right-in-front-of-his-eyes interest. Hamill's youthful overacting is a pleasure to watch in itself.This film has aged well and has some really funny moments, like Hamill hitchhiking encounter with a lowrider fleet creeping to Vegas. Hamill and Potts are really in their prime here, Hamill maybe too much so, he was in an auto-accident following production which dramatically changed the looks preserved in "Summer." Take a look at "The Empire Strikes Back" and compare.
summary: Corvette Summer...summer release...what a concept!!!

reviewText: I was 13 when this first came out, and I remember seeing it in theatres.  Back then, everyone was hot on Hamill from Star Wars.  But this film showed another side of him.  I remember it being a bit risque in parts (the whole hooker stuff, etc. - but it was the 70's).  I've always wanted to get it on DVD and was glad to finally pick it up.  Watching it again - I was back to 1978 again and enjoying it.  The movie pace keeps solid and its a tale that holds up pretty much with time.  Except for the music and clothes and some of the references to salaries, the story is pretty timeless: boy makes car, boy loses car, boy looks for car, boy finds love and the car.  It's a classic.
summary: I was 13 when this first came out..

reviewText: I remember this as a kid...Mark Hamill had just come off "Star Wars" when he did this film, however, he was involved in a car crash shortly after finishing "Star Wars" which altered his facial appearance as seen here & in the "Star Wars" sequels, he had to undergo facial reconstruction, but in this he is Kenny Dantley who is a auto-mechanics shop student at his high school who becomes smitten with a newly rebuilt customized Corvette Stingray, the car is stolen & he is beside himself, however he learns that the car has been seen in Las Vegas & shortly ventures out to find the car, & what follows is a lot fun as he hitchhikes from L.A. & is soon picked up by a young & beautiful Annie Potts, one of the few women to age well in Hollywood, here she is Vanessa, a free-spirited hooker-wanna-be, with a unique van that has a waterbed in the back, I don't think I have seen a van like this since in a film or T.V, it definately screams 70's retro style, but that is part of the fun here, they soon after a series of playing hard to get become close & Kenny manages to track down his Corvette & discovers that it is now in the hands of a chop shop operation, he then gets a startling revelation that his high shop teacher was involved in the theft, & is coerced into working for this band of thieves, the ring leader reluctantly hires Kenny at the urging of his teacher in an effort to keep the operation quiet, however I liked the ring leader's awesome black Camaro better, Kenny accepts the offer against his better judgement & later tries to inpress Vanessa with his new found wealth, however she is not impressed as she realizes that he has been corrupted & cuts all ties with him, he recants & decides that the money isn't worth losing her over & decides to steal back the Corvette which results in one cool car chase that could only come from the 70's, the chemistry between Hamill & Potts is good & this is an all around fun film, you realize how much Las Vegas has changed since the 70's, watch any episode of "C.S.I" & you will see much has changed since 1978, it is clear that Mark Hamill wanted to do somthing different to avoid being type-cast as Luke Skywalker, sadly, he never branched out like say Harrison Ford did, but you can't blame him for trying, great 70's nostalgia here.
summary: Still a fun movie....hands down...

reviewText: I watched this film yesterday (streaming from Netflix) and I'll have to say that it was a fun film to watch as our summer starts to come to an end.  I was hesitant to watch this because it's probably going to be another campy dated seventies teen flick (like The Van, Aloha Bobby and Rose, Car Wash, etc.) but it was a bit more realistic drama than any kind of comedy that's hard to appreciate being over 30 years old.But, I enjoyed this.  Mark Hamill played Kenny, a typical white trash high school student in the Los Angeles area, who lives with his sleezy white trash mother in a trailer park, and who has poor grades at school, but, has a passion for working on and restoring cars.  His first love in this film was to restore a Stingray Corvette.No sooner does he and some fellow students completely restore this Stingray Corvette, during a friend's test drive of the Corvette, it is stolen almost immediately.Kenny posts a picture of his Corvette at a gas station he works at, hoping someone will have seen it. He gets a clue from a passer-by that thinks he saw Kenny's Corvette in Las Vegas, so Kenny is determined to find his Corvette so he heads to Las Vegas.  There he meets who is soon to be is second love, a call girl wannabe named Vanessa, played by Annie Potts.Now, who in their right mind, could not love and appreciate Annie Potts?  She's cute as hell, has an adorable Bronx accent, and has incredible patience for Kenny as they work together to help his find his stolen Corvette.  Of course, Kenny's Corvette is there, but when he finally confronts the thieves, he learns that the conspiracy of the thief began at home with his auto body teacher (Ed McGrath) back at school in Los Angeles.  So, Kenny is confronted by his teacher, and is offered a job with the car thieves who also restore cars (although they restore stolen cars).  Kenny agrees but he has an alternate intention as he plays along till he and Vanessa make their move to get back his stolen Stingray Corvette.Yes, this was a great film to end my summer.  If this came out on Blu-Ray, I'd buy it.
summary: Novelty film for Star Wars's Mark Hamill fans

reviewText: This movie I saw years ago and I liked it then. This is a movie about a high school teenager. The shop teacher takes the class to a wrecking yard to pick out a car to repair. This young boy sees this lettering fall to the ground near him and picks it up. He sees that it states "Corvette". He than looks for where it came from and see that its from a car that is on the way to be smashed. He realizes that its a corvette stringray. So this ends up beginning the car that they take. The young teen spends 24/7 working on the car. He knows a lot about cars, but he has no girlfriend. He see other guys with girls and making out with them. He is a shy young man and doesn't know how to be with a girl. He does all this work on this car and it ends up beautiful. They the class take the car for a ride. What none of them knew is that their shop teacher has it all planned for someone to steal it. When it taken this young man is all set on finding it. He puts pictures up everywhere and finally someone see it. So the young teen goes to find it. He tries to hitch a ride with a number of people. Then this one van rolls up and its Anne Potts. She gives him a ride and she is telling him how she intends to make a lot of money being a hooker in Vegas. She even tries to make him her first customer. He gets shy and it really cute to see him get nervous. He does fine that the vette is in Vegas. This girl ends up trying to fine the car with him. They end up falling in love with each other. He does get the car back and takes it to the school. The crooked teacher tries to talk to him and the young man just walks away from him. I loved this movie and am keeping it for my collections.
summary: This is a cute movie.

reviewText: What would you do if something you put all your time and hard work into was suddenly gone? For Ken Dantley played by (Mark Hamill) he's about to do everything he possibly can to find his beloved Corvette.It's not just a car! The DVD release of "Corvette Summer" has finally replaced my old worn out VHS copy taped from television. Kudos' to Warner Home Video for finally releasing this classic 70's car movie on DVD. It's a barebones release as far as DVD's go, but I'll take it just the way it is. The video transfer is really nice and the sound is really good. It's too bad the sound wasn't remastered in 5.1 Dolby Digital given its awesome soundtrack.No matter how many times I see this movie, I still find it very entertaining and fun to watch. The story is ok and the interaction between Mark Hamill and Annie Potts characters is always hilarious no matter how many times I see it. I have to admit; watching Annie Potts play the part of a skinny wannabe hooker is completely outrageous and pretty hilarious. In the end this movie is really all about the car and what a car it is!DVD Features:Play MovieScene SelectionsTheatrical TrailerLanguages: English & FrenchSubtitles: English, French & Spanish (Feature Film Only)
summary: IT'S  NOT JUST A CAR !

reviewText: After Star Wars became the greatest phenomeon in Hollywood history and Mark Hamill shot to stardom as the legendary Luke Skywalker, he returned to the big screen in a less known adventure film from 1978 called "Corvette Summer" Hamill stars as car loving teen who cruises around Las Vegas looking for his red corvette he made from wreckage and he meets and falls for a good hearted,but a little horny teenage prostitute wannabe played by Ghostbusters' Annie Potts. The two teens fall for each other and gets his hot wheels back. it's an okay movie, nothing special, but not a bad movie, I've seen much worse from Tom Green to David Spade. If you love Star Wars, give it a try for another film credit of Mark Hamill.
summary: Luke Skywalker is looking for a "Little Red Corvette" and falling for a hooker

reviewText: After Star Wars was released Mark Hammil stared in this movie about his dream car which he came across in a junk yard and supped up and heavily customized during his high school senior year.  While working on it, he fell in love with it, the rest is theatrical history.  A great movie if your a guy who appreciates cars, the seventies culture of customized cars. traveling and high speed chases.  While not one of Hammil's high points in his career, it should not be avoided, poo-pooed or disdained.  It is well acted, while the characters would not show much depth as say a well acted drama or Shakespeare it does show some of the fun of finally owning one's first car and the thrill of practically creating it from scratch.
summary: Mark Hammil, Cars: i.e. Corvettes, and 1970's obsession.

reviewText: WOW, it's finally here!I actually never thought I'd see this one on DVD, a true classic. It's strange to see Mark Hamill (Luke Skywalker) chasing after Corvettes, but this is 1978, and He apparently had some time between Star Wars films. Another interesting fact, the actor that portrayed the car thief, Kim Milford, also starred in the film "Laserblast" that same year. He seems to have a resemblance to Mark Hamill in a weird sort of way. Corvette Summer, a Fun movie if anything. The Car is nice, but Annie Potts is the real star here.
summary: Corvette Summer (DVD)
